He wore a blue round about jacket, black silk vest and black jeans pantaloons, with a slouched hat considerably worn.
I will pay the above reward for his return to my house or to the Cary Street Jail.

div3.head: $20 reward.
div3.p: --Ran away from our mill, on the Williamsburg Stage Road, in Henrico county about six weeks age, a Negro man, named Ned. 24 years old. at out 5 ½ feet high slender frame and dark ginger-break color, and downcast expression when spoken to. We will give $10 if arrested in this county or city, and $20 if in any other county.

C. E. & W. E. Anderson.
de 12--4t

div3.head: Attention, Fayette artillery.
div3.p:
--Assemble at your Armory, on Cary st., between 11th and 12th sts., this (Wednesday) evening, Dec. 12th, at 7 ½ o'clock, for Company Drill and meeting.
It is earnestly requested that every member should be present, as business of importance will be put before the Company.
div3.closer:
By order of Capt. Cabell.
Jas. N. Clark, 1st Serg't. de 12--1t

div3.head:
38d Reg't Virginia militia.
December 11, 1860.
div3.p: An adjourned Court of inquiry, for the 20 Battalion, for the assessment of fines on delinquents at musters during the year will be held at the office of Cabell & Sands on Thursday, the 13th inst., at 11 o'clock A. M. Persons liable to fines will please attend and present their excuses.

div3.head:
Hdqr's 33d Reg't Va. Militia.
December 10, 1860.
div3.p: Order No. 8.
An adjourned meeting of the Board of Officers of the 33d Regiment, will be held at the office of Maj, Johnson H. Sands, on Saturday, the 15th inst, at 11 o'clock
div3.closer:

W. H. Pryor, Adj't. de 10--td

div3.head: Married.
div3.p:
On Thursday, Dec. 6th, at Capt. Corr's, King William county, Va., by Dr. H. Edwards.
Jno, R. Warstaton, of Williamsburg, Va., and Edna W. Lipscomb, of the former place.

div4.p:
On the 11th instant at half-past 7 o'clock, Wm. B Crabbin.
aged 7 years and 6 months.
His funeral will take place this day at 10 o'clock, from the residence of his father in law. on Clay, between 17th and 18th streets. The friends and acquaintances are invited to attend.

In Surry county, November 21st. of putrid sore throat, Mary Jane.
daughter of John A. and Elizabeth Conway, in the 7th year of her age.

div2.head:
Marine intelligence.
port of Richmond, December 11.
high water this day (Wednesday) 4 o'clock.

div3.p: Sailed.

Steamship Roanoke, Couch, New York, mdze.
and passengers, Ludlam & Watson.
Steamer Geo. Peabody, Pritchard, Baltimore, mdze and passengers, D. & W. Currie.

Steamer City of Richmond Mitchell, Philadelphia.
mdze, and passengers, C. P. Cardozo.
Schr Roxanna, Moore, Norfolk, mdze., W. D Co quitt & o.
Schr. Wm S Triplett, Pritchett, Baltimore, flour, Wm. Colquitt & Co.
Schr. Gallego, Smith, New York, mdze., D. & W. Currie
Schr. Rebecca, McGee, down the river, light.

div3.head: Fall River, Dec. 7.
div3.p: --Sailed, schr. Susan and Mary, Norfolk.
Boston, Dec. 8,--Arrived, schr. Lucy Ames, Rappahannock.
New York, Dec. 10.--Cleared, schr. Margaret, Petersburg.

Norfolk, Dec. 10.--Arrived schrs.
Mountaineer, York River; Bowden, Warwick; H. W. Collins, Richmond; Mary and Virginia, do; Mary L. Johnston, do.

div4.head: [by Telegraph.]
div4.p: Hampton Roads, Dec. 11--Arrived, ship Grey hound, 156 days from Rio, with 4,000 bags of coffee; ship Buena Vista, 121 days from Baker a Island.

div3.head: For Hire
div3.p: --A likely young Woman, for the balance of this and the ensuing year; said to be a plain Cook, Ironer and Washer.
div3.closer:
Ro. B Lyne.
Agent for Hiring out Negroes, &c.,
Office, Motrop tan Ball. de 12--2t

div3.head: For Hire
div3.p:
--For the ensuing twelve months, a strong and healthy Negro Girl, to act as seamstress and lady's maid.
Price $75. For particulars, call at the residence of Mr. John Turpin.
corner of 31 and Cary streets.

div3.head: For sale
div3.p:
--At Gradv's Jail a No. 1 Box Maker.
Will be sold on accommodating terms.
If immediate application is made.

div3.head: A no. 1 Carpenter for sale.
div3.p: --We have for private sale, a likely Negro man 30 years of age, who is a No. 1 Carpenter; of good mo al character, and sold for no fault.
div3.closer:
Apply to
Pulliam & Co.,
Odd Fellows' Hall, Franklin st. oc 18--ts

div3.head: Cook for sale
div3.p: --We have for sale a young Negro Woman, aged twenty years. She is an A No. 1 Bread, Meat and Pastry Cook, and good Washer and Ironer.
div3.closer:
Pulliam & Co. Aucts.,
Odd Fellows' Hall, Franklin st.

div3.head: Henrico light Dragoons!
div3.p:
Meet in citizens' dress.
at the County Court-House, at 11 A. M., on Thursday.
the 13th of December, for the transaction of important business.
div3.closer:
By order of Col. Davis.
John F. Huffman. 1st Serg't. de 10--4t

div3.head: Grays, attention
div3.p:
--Attend Company Drills, at Military Hall, every Wednesday and Friday nights.
at 7 ½ o'clock, in jackets and undress caps, until further notice.
div3.closer:
By order of Capt. Elliott.
E. W. Branch, 1st Serg't. de 10--5t

figure.figDesc: Page image of Daily Dispatch, Volume 18, Number 140, page 3.

div3.head:
Later from Europe.
Arrival of the Europa!

div4.p: --The steamship Europa arrived off Cape Race yesterday, with Liverpool dates to the 1st, and Queenstown dates to the 2d inst.
The Atlantic and Edinburg had arrived out.
The general news is unimportant.
Italian affairs had undergone no change.--The garrison of Gaeta had made a sortie, but were repulsed with great loss.

The American money crisis has caused specie shipments.
The Europa has a considerable amount, and large shipments are expected to be made by the Atlantic.
These movements caused a renewal of gold withdrawals from Bank on the 30th.

div4.head: Commercial.
div4.p:
--Cotton sales for the week 70,000 bales. The market ruled firm, with a good trade demand and closing firm on Friday at full prices and a slight advance.
Stock in port 535,000 bales including 490,000 American.
Breadstuffs have a downward tendency, except Corn, which is steady.
Provisions steady.
Consols 93¼. 93¾ Bullion increased 403,000.--Bank rates reduced to 5 per cent. Money very active.

div3.head: Congressional.
div3.p: --Senate.--The bill to admit Kansas was made the special order of the day for next Tuesday.
The Military Committee were instructed to report if the expenses of the War Department cannot be reduced.
Mr. Powell's resolutions were again taken up.
Mr. Bigler, of Pa, made a Union speech.
Mr. Pugh, of Ala., was in favor of the Union, but favored the rights of the South, too.

A running debate ensued between Messrs. Pugh and Iverson, of Ga.; Douglas, of Ill..; Tea Eyck, of New Jersey; Green, of Mo.; Fitch, of Ind; Powell, of Ky; Wade, of Ohio, and others, on the same subject.
Mr. Mason, of Va., said we are satisfied, unless we can have other evidences by conventions in all the States, that we are not bound to remain in the Union.
Messrs. Collamer, of Vt.; Wigfall, of Texas, and Davis, of Miss., interchanged their views, and pending the subject, the Senate.
Adjourned.

House.--Mr. Cobb, of Ala., said what was necessary to be done to save the Union, should be done at once, as Alabama had called a Convention with a view of going out. He wanted the select committee to go to work and see what could be done.

Mr. Davis, of Miss., did not believe any good would result from the deliberations of the Committee, yet he would consent to serve on it. believed any proposition to quiet the present disturbances should emanate from the Republicans.
He believed the Constitution, It carried out in letter and spirit, would be sufficient, without a resort to legislative enactments or compromises.
The House refused to excuse Mr. Hawkins, of Florida, from serving on the Committee, by a vote of 96 years to 101 noes.
Mr. Hawkins then said he would not serve.
Mr. Boyce, of South Carolina, asked to be excused from serving on the Committee.

Mr. Smith, of Virginia, said he was surprised the Republicans should shirk the debate.
He was in hopes that the views of every section would have been presented, and wished to see what the Committee would present for the action of the House, and whether anything could be done to allay the present excitement.
The House refused to excuse Mr. Boyce.
Mr. Morrill, of Vermont, asked to be excused, but was refused.

Mr. Stanton, of Ohio, had no hope that the Committee could do anything, and did not see any use of premature discussion.
He saw no cause for legislation.
Mr. Hindman, of Arkansas, wished to offer something practical, viz: amendments to the Constitution for the protection of Southern rights.
Mr. Morris, of Illinois, objected.
Mr. Sherman, from the Committee of Ways and Means, reported the Diplomatic, Consular and Indian Appropriation bills, which were referred.
Adjourned.

div4.p:
--The Democrats from the Northwest have had several conferences relative to the present condition of political affairs.
They generally adopt the positions set forth yesterday in the speeches of Vallandigham and McClelland — that the Union cannot be dissolved peaceably, and that the Northwest will under no circumstances consent to be cut off from the Gulf of Mexico and city of New York, and that the Federal Government, whatever may be its faults, is of inestimable value.
The leading idea here is a central government, embracing the middle, Western, and border slave States.
Lieut, Gen. Winfield Scott will arrive here to-morrow.

div4.head: [Second Dispatch.]
div4.p: Secretary Toucey was to-day requested by the President to act as Secretary of the Treasury, in addition to his duties in the Navy Department, until Hon. Howell Cobb's successor is appointed.

Mr. Cobb took formal leave of the President to-day, and will leave the city to-morrow.
He has prepared a letter to the people of Georgia, calling on them to arise in all their manhood and be prepared on the 4th of March to announce and maintain their independence out of the Union, saying they will never again have equality and justice in it. He entertains no doubt either of their right or duty to secede.

div3.head: New Jersey Convention.
div3.p: --The Convention to consider the dangers threatening the Union is largely attended.
Col. Wm. C. Alexander was chosen President.

Com. Stockton, chairman of the committee to prepare an address, presented an address and resolutions, both of which were adopted amid much confusion.
His address declares that the North has committed greet wrongs against the South, and must retrace her steps by repealing all laws preventing the execution of the Fugitive Slave Law, and allowing all citizens of the Southern States to travel North with their property.
All this the South has a clear right to, and looks not for indemnity for the past, but security for the future.

div3.head: Later from Mexico.
div3.p: --The steamship Tennessee, from Vera Cruz on the 7th, has advices from the City of Mexico to the 28th ultimo.

The Liberals had completely invested the city.
There was much distress among the inhabitants in consequence of the scarcity of supplies.
The main body of the Liberal army had not come up.
An express from Mexico on the 3d, by which news of the capture or repulse was expected, had not arrived at Vera Cruz when the steamer left.
Mr. McLane and his legation were to return home by the next steamer.
The French minister advises Miramon to capitulate.

div3.head: Meeting of the Louisiana Legislature.
div3.p:
--The Legislature met to-day.
A resolution organizing a military system for the State was adopted.
A resolution calling a State Convention and giving the reasons for it, the election of Lincoln and hostility of the North, was introduced in the Senate, and referred to a joint committee.
A preamble and resolutions were offered, taking the ground that the States which have nullified the Fugitive Slave Law have no right to vote for President.

div3.head: The Philadelphia Union meeting.
div3.p: --Mayor Henry issued his proclamation this morning for a Union meeting to-morrow at noon. Bishop Potter will open the proceedings with prayer.

div3.head: $20 reward.
div3.p: --Ran away on Saturday, the 3d inst., from the employment of Dr. John B. Eastham, of Louisa county, a Negro man, named Ralph, belonging to the estate of Jesse Perkins, dec'd.

Ralph is about twenty-two years of age black, about five feet five inches high; one of his front teeth is out, and the rest are very broad and white.
No peculiar mark about him is remembered, but we think he has a scar between his forefinger and thumb on one of his hands — can't say which.
He, it is said, can write a good hand, and is probably making his way to a free State.--The above reward will be paid for his apprehension in the State and delivery to us, or being placed in a jail so that we get him; or, if taken out of the State and delivered to us, or placed in a jail in this State, so that we get him, a reward of $100 will be paid.
div3.closer:
Wm Crawford,
John R. Quarles,
Frank T. West,
Ex'ors of Jesse Perkins, dec'd.
Trevillian's Depot, Louisa co., no 14--ts
Nov. 12th 1860. no 14--ts

div3.head: Negro Clothing, Negro Clothing
div3.p:
--Darracott, Harris & Co. have on hand an unusually large stock of Clothing for Servants, and wishing to reduce their stock as much as possible, will sell their Negro Clothing lower than ever before offered.
They would, therefore, invite all in want to give them a call, as they are determined to sell, regardless of profit.
div3.closer:
Darracott, Harris & Co.,
No. 112 Main street.

figure.figDesc: Page image of Daily Dispatch, Volume 18, Number 140, page 4.

div3.head: The Feeding of Paris.
div3.p:
The annual account of the receipts and expenditures of the city of Paris, for the year 1859, has just been published by the municipality, and possesses this year, besides its usual statistical points of interest, the additional one of being the last document of the kind which will be put forth under the old limits of the city.
The budget for 1860, which cannot appear till next year, will naturally contain the details of the increased receipts and expenditures caused by the extension of the city to the fortifications, under the working of the law of June, 1859.
It appears by the present document that the receipts for the past year have amounted to about 110 millions of francs, whist the expenditure has reached the sum of 98 millions. One of the principal sources of the receipts is, as usual, the octopi, or tax on eatables and drinkables, combustibles and other objects entering the city gates, which figure in the above account to the amount of 54 millions of francs, an increase on the last ten years of nearly 21 millions in this single branch of revenue.

It is already calculated that the 100,000 inhabitants added to the usual population of Paris by the extension of its limits, will cause the octopi to reach, for 1860, the sum of 66,000,000.
Of the 54,000,000 thus obtained, the drinkables contribute 27,000,000, being 3,000,000 more than in the previous year.
It is remarked that the immense extension given in the last two years to the building trade, has caused a rise of from 1,000,000 hectoliters of lime and plaster to 20,000,000 of the same materials.
To give an idea of the consumption of Paris, it is stated that, in the various markets of the city, game and poultry have been sold to the amount of 19,000,000; butter and eggs to that of 12,000,000; fruits and vegetables to 3,000,000; fish to 8,000,000, and oysters to 2,000,000--the tax on these several articles bringing nearly 4,000,000 into the city coffers.

The consumption of butchers' meat has considerably increased since the trade has been thrown open, there being an increase of 7,000,000 of kilos (or 14,000,000 of pounds) within the last two years. Among the other receipts the dog tax is computed to bring into the city nearly 300,000 francs, whilst the diminution in the canine race has been reckoned at no less than from 42,000 in 1855 to 29,000 in the year 1859.
The tax on right of entry at the Bourse, continued in spite of all representations on the subject by the financial press, brings in upwards of 700,000 francs.

div3.head: Scene at a Post-office.
div3.p:
--Bridget — Can't ye give me thim three ba'penny stamps!
I'm anxious this hour, Mister.
Clerk (sharply)--Madam, this is not the ladies' window; I've told you so twice before.
Bridget — An' sure the Lord spare you your health, sir; I'm no lady, but a working girl, glad to earn $6 a month.
The stamps were handed over.
